Authors: Rui Du, Genevieve Gates, Yu Cheng Dai
Title:
Five new species of Sidera (Hymenochaetales,
Basidiomycota)
Abstract:
Five new species in the genus Sidera, S. australiana, S.
minutissima, S. parallela, S. srilankensis and S. tenuis, are described
based on morphological characteristics and phylogenetic analyses.
Phylogenetic analyses based on the internal transcribed spacer (ITS)
regions and nuclear large subunit (nLSU) ribosomal RNA gene regions
indicated that these five species nested within the Sidera clade and
formed five lineages with good supports. S. australiana is characterized
by buff to olivaceous buff basidiocarps when dry, relatively big pores
(57 per mm), rarely presence of rosette-like crystals, and allantoid
basidiospores measuring 3.74.3 × 1.01.3 μm. S. minutissima is
characterized by its tiny basidiocarps, generative hyphae dominant at
dissepiment edges, the presence of cystidioles, and allantoid
basidiospores measuring 3.84.4 × 0.91.3 μm. S. parallela differs from
other species in the genus by its parallel tramal hyphae and lunate
basidiospores measuring 2.83.3 × 0.91.2 μm. S. srilankensis is
characterized by both generative hyphae and skeletal hyphae dominant at
dissepiment edges, and lunate basidiospores measuring 3.54.0 × 1.01.3
μm. S. tenuis is distinguished from other species in the genus by small
pores (810 per mm) and long and allantoid basidiospores measuring 4.25.0
× 0.81.0 μm.
